THREE YEARS' WORK!

A STRIKING ILLUSTRATION OF ONE MAN'S SUCCESS

IN FERTILE MANITOBA.

MANITOBA.

GENERAL FEATURES.

Manitoba has not a continuous stretch of level prairie, but on the contrary, is broken into a varied and diversified character, and presents a variety of topography. In the South it is broken by the Red River Valley, in the East by the Rocky Mountains, and in the North by the Riding Mountain Range. The central portion has large areas of forest broken by numerous lakes and river valleys, and are almost entirely covered with timber.

RICHEST SOIL IN THE WORLD.

The soil is a rich, deep, black, argillaceous mould, or loam, resting on a firm and very tenacious clay subsoil. It is among the richest, if not the finest, soils in the world, and especially adapted to the growth of grain. Many of the farms in Scotland and Germany have been abandoned. This vast extent of the prairie soil has arisen from the decayed remains of trees, birds and animals and ashes of prairie fires, together with decayed vegetable matter, which has been mixed with a red clay subsoil. It is therefore a soil stored in wealth in the soil that the agriculturist need for any further investment.

EXPERIMENT SURPLUS.

The wheat grown in Manitoba is eagerly sought after by the millers of Europe, owing to its superior quality and hardiness, considered the finest type of any wheat grown in the World.
CLIMATE.

The climate in summer and cold in winter. The temperature in very nearly the same as that of the United States. In winter the thermometer sinks to zero. The atmosphere, however, is not so dry as that of the United States. Warm clothing, therefore, is not required. The climate is generally healthy, and there are no diseases peculiar to the province or the climate.

AN ARMY OF SELF-BINDERS.

HARVESTING BY WHOLESALE.

CANADIAN NORTH-WEST CROPS MAKE SUCCESS SURE.
THE CYPRESS HILLS COUNTRY.

The Cypress Hills are the only range of hills in the South from the Railway, and are well adapted for stock raising and as their elevation is sufficient to prevent them from being an uncertainty, the grass land that will be found there will not likely be disturbed by the snows of winter or the storms of spring, never failing to provide good pasture ground for his stock. WHAT CAN BE DONE!

The First Year in Manitoba.

A practical farmer of some years residence in Manitoba makes the following statement:

Land can be purchased cheaply here, or it can be had for nothing by homesteading. This enables farmers with small capital to commence farming. It is all plain sailing; no stamps or stones to take out; all level prairie land ready for the plough. A farmer can begin on a small capital. A single man can start on an outlay of $350, made up as follows—a yoke of oxen and harness, $175; plow, harrow, etc., $10; stove and furniture, $40; bedding, etc., $20; lumber, tools, windows, etc., or log shanty, $50; provisions, $60; seed, $50. A farmer with a family of five, would have to lay out $140 more, bringing his outlay up to $925.

A farmer can come about the middle of May, select his land and build his shanty; he can commence to plough about the 5th of April; he can break 10 acres and put it under crop on the sod; then continue breaking for two months after he puts the 10 acres under crop, and can easily break thirty acres, and harvest the 10 acres in the fall, ready for crop in the spring. He can raise enough on the ten acres to give him a start; he can cut hay enough for his oxen and a cow in July, and it will cost him about $50 additional to seed the forty acres in the spring.

Suppose he puts in 40 acres of wheat, and raises 25 bushels to the acre, at 80 cents per bushel, it will be worth $800; say 5 acres of oats at 40 bushels per acre, at 35 cents per bushel, $70; say 1 acre of potatoes, 200 bushels, at 40 cents, $80; 3 acres of barley, 10 bushels per acre, worth 40 cents, $120; and 1 acre of garden stuff at $1.20; total, $918. After deducting expenses of harvesting and the whole original outlay, the farmer will still have something to the good to start with next year. Young farmers should take a note of this, and secure land in this country before it is all taken up.

WHAT CAN BE DONE!

Butter Making in Alberta.

A practical man in Alberta, makes the following statement about Butter making in Alberta—

A settler arrives here having means to put up a small house on his future homestead, and has also means to get a span of horses, a plough and harrow, with enough of seed to plant a few acres. Then, if he has a wife, and $100 left, let him buy two cows; if more money still, more cows—say five cows the first year. From these he will be able to make five pounds of butter daily during five months, worth in our market 25 cents a pound (1s.). This will support himself and wife. The milk will also feed three calves and a couple of pigs. Now, it must be remembered that the care of the cows not prevent him from cultivating a good garden and attending to several hundred of acres of grass and grain. And it must be also remembered, in connection with all this, that no matter how favorable the season may be, the garden and the cultivated acres may prove a failure, but neither hail-storm nor frost affect the returns from properly attended milch cows.

Of course, the above applies to individual beginnings of an industry that will unavoidably merge into a co-operative dairy farming, when the creamery will be established in the centre of the township, where the individual or company will gather the cream from the surrounding farmers, and employ a practical and trained butter-maker, who will produce from the uniform and unequalled cream of Alberta, the gilt-edged creamery butter of commerce, unsurpassed, if equalled, by any in the world.
COST OF RAILWAY TICKETS REFUNDED.

The Company has been informed that the Company's tickets will be refunded if the holder purchases land from the Company. In this way, land hunters are enabled to purchase land at a lower price than they would have paid otherwise.

SOUTHERN MANITOBA LANDS.

Southern Manitoba is called to the notice of the Manitoba Southern Railway Company, administered by the same department as that which administers the lands of the Canadian Pacific.

There are several difficulties which have now passed away. The lands of Southern Manitoba were for a long time looked upon as being of no value. In the meantime, all the available government lands in Southern Manitoba have been sold, so that at the time the railway line was opened, there was not enough land available for sale.

The section of country is well wooded.

There are many trees of various kinds and ages, some of them being very old, while others are still young. The soil is very fertile, and the trees grow rapidly.

WILD FRUITS AROUND.

There are many wild fruits growing around, such as blackberries, raspberries, wild plums, gooseberries, and currants, also red and black cherries.

GAME.

There are many animals living around, including deer, moose, and other game birds. There are also many species of wild animals, such as bears, foxes, and raccoons.

FISH.

There are many fish living in the streams and ponds, including trout, salmon, and other species of fish.
ADVICE TO SETTLERS.

The newcomer need not fear that when he reaches Winnipeg he will fall into the hands of thieves, impostors, or unfriendly people. If he follows the directions of this pamphlet, he will put himself in the hands of true friends, who will look after him. The train is met upon its arrival by the agents of the Government and of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, who take charge of Immigrants and give them all the assistance and advice they need in a strange land.

CHOOSING A LOCATION.

In cases where they have already fixed upon some locality for settlement, where friends are awaiting them, they are shown how to proceed directly to that point. If they have not decided upon such a locality, but intend to seek a home somewhere further West, they should immediately call upon the Land Commissioner of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company.

THE PRICE OF RAILWAY LANDS,

Their proximity to a railway station or marker, the amount of settlement, the past history of people in the neighborhood, and the exact character of the soil can be learned at his office. Every quarter section of land has been surveyed by the Railway Company and a plan of each section is shown on the map. It is also reported upon in detail.

All this information is open to the intending settler. If the land of a given section is sandy, or rocky, or marshy, or otherwise unsuitable for farming, he is told so; if it is good land for growing, but poor for farming, he learns that; if it is thoroughly fertile and desirable, that will be pointed out. In short, the whole truth, whether it is favorable or unfavorable, can be learned from the maps and surveyor's notes shown in this office.

PERSONAL INSPECTION.

Most men, nevertheless, naturally wish to examine for themselves the section which seems to them from these reports most suitable, and this is strongly recommended in every case. They are then told what is the nearest and cheapest way to reach it, (special facilities being provided for this purpose), and, when necessary, are furnished by the Dominion Government Intelligence Officer with a guide, who either accompanies them all the way from Winnipeg, or meets them at the nearest railway station, and assists them in every way during their stay. If they are pleased (which is usually the case), all the arrangements for their stay, or for its purchase, are made at once, and the immigrant, therefore, need delay between the arrival of an immigrant at Winnipeg and his settlement upon the land of his choice.

WHERE SHOULD I GO?

If you want to confine your farming purely to grain growing, select your land in

MANITOBA OR EASTERN ASSINIBOIA,

getting as close to a railway station as possible. If for cattle, horse or sheep raising,

WESTERN ASSINIBOIA OR ALBERTA.

Mixed farming can be carried on to advantage in any of these Provinces.

NO CUSTOMS TROUBLES! NO TRANSFERS!

Passengers from Europe, Homemakers, Tourists and Sportsmen, leave the Trans-Atlantic Steamer at Quebec, in summer, and at Halifax, Nova Scotia, during the winter months. At either of these points they will be met by an agent of the Company, who will take charge of them, see after baggage, and furnish all needful information concerning the journey.

No Railway in America offers so many accommodations to SECOND CLASS or COLONIST Passengers at so little expense as does the CANADIAN PACIFIC. Colonists are able to travel to NEW HOMES in MANITOBA, the NORTH-WEST, or BRITISH COLUMBIA, with nearly as great comfort as First Class Passengers.

COLONIST SLEEPING CARS.

The Cars devoted to the use of Colonists are taken upon the same fast trains with the first class cars, and every one is a sleeping car, going through WITHOUT CHANGE to the PACIFIC COAST. These cars are similar in size, windows, and ventilation to the first class cars, but are not upholstered. The seats are arranged in pairs facing each other on each side of the car, are of comfortable shape, and are made so that they can be joined into a berth, ready for the reception of a man,太太 and a child. Every passenger has a single berth and a bedlet is furnished for it; EXACTLY the SAME as in FIRST CLASS SLEEPER. Over each pair of seats a broad upper berth, hinged against the wall of the car, can be let down and form an additional sleeping place. No Extra Charge is made for these Sleeping Accommodations; they are a part of the Regular Car. Second Class Passengers, however, must provide their own bedding. If they do not bring it with them, a complete outfit of mattress, pillow, blanket and curtains may be bought of the Agent of the Company at the point of starting at a cost of $2.50. (These articles become the property of the purchaser.) The curtains may be hung around the berth, turning it into a little private room. SMOKING IS NOT PERMITTED in any part of this car.

For further information apply to

ARCHER BAKER,
European Traffic Agent.
